intro: Ommatodium, commonly known as the "eye-like structure" of certain plants, is a specialized botanical feature found in some species of ferns and mosses. It refers to the small, lens-shaped structures that are part of the reproductive system in these plants. These structures are typically composed of a central stalk with surrounding cells that aid in spore production. Ommatodia are often arranged in clusters, contributing to the plant's overall reproductive efficiency. Their unique morphology plays a crucial role in the dispersal of spores in moist, shaded environments.
